messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nunome-zogan
messages.msgSnippet: Peter, Agreed. I don t know anything about the Korean version of nunome but I ll look into it.  It is interesting that we have well preserved true inlay on
messages.messageBody:
Peter,
Agreed.

I don't know anything about the Korean version of nunome but I'll look into it. It is interesting that we have well preserved "true" inlay on Kofun period fittings and even swords, as well as pieces with sheet gold overlay but no nunome examples. It is hard to believe that the technique was unknown or unexploited prior to the Muromachi period.

Jim







Peter,
My impression is that nunome zogan first appears on Japanese sword fittings
in the late Muromachi period.

Jim

Jim and Others,
Thanks for the replies. I too have noted that the technique we call
nunome turns up in lots of premodern metal working traditions. In addition
to those noted, I have seen it on Tibetan and "Chinese" stuff, most notably
in our area of interest on Chinese "Namban" tsuba, for example. The
explicit item that triggered my question is an iron six-sided vase I have
with heavy (but not very attractive) silver overlay that I think is Korean.
Does anyone know the Korean word for such stuff, by the way?
I have also noted that the earliest apparent occurrences of this
technique on Japanese stuff all seem to have a Muromachi sort of age. Given
its apparent world-wide distribution of the technique, it must have either
been introduced or invented in Japan at that time, OR, older stuff has not
survived. I tend to favor the later idea.
It is possible, I betcha, that the fine iron striations that hold the
gold/silver on, simply won't survive more than about 500 years. If they
largely oxidize away in that kind of time frame, all older examples would
be gone so it would look like nunome suddenly appeared.
Let me add, in closing, that virtually all of the techniques Japanese
kinko use do show up in other parts of the world and other artistic
traditions. The Japanese like to see themselves as innovators in this
regard, but what they really did, IMHO, is bring basic techniques to high
levels of virtuosity. This weekend I bought a couple of swords. One is a
rather ordinary nippon-to, but the other a really nice cuphilt (Spanish?)
rapier that is embellished with light repousse, good horidashi engraving,
and a wonderfully even "nanako-ishime" finish that is as nice as any on an
iron tsuba. Craftsmanship is where we find it, mebbe.

Peter Bleed
Associate Dean
College of Arts and Sciences
1223 Oldfather Hall
University of Nebraska
Lincoln, NE 68588-0312
(402) 472-2891




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nunome-zogan
messages.msgSnippet: Also, patinated shakudo alloys were used in the Middle East as early as the 19th C BCE. Jim ... Jim and all, It is interesting to see the geographic
messages.messageBody:
Also, patinated "shakudo" alloys were used in the Middle East as early as
the 19th C BCE.

Jim
---------

Jim and all,

It is interesting to see the geographic connections, especially since the
Japanese "invented" all of these techniques and motifs, right? (Reminds me
of the Greeks, the Italians, etc.) See part of "Lies My Teachers Taught Me"
by Bob Haynes in the most recent To-Ron for further comments along these
lines.

I just saw an Indian dagger in the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco that
had gold inlay on the blade done this way no doubt, actually in the kind of
tendril designs we see so often on Japanese metalwork. It had a walrus ivory
handle, a very attractive item. Unfortunately my notes on it's date and
place are temporarily inaccessible, and my digital camera batteries died
just after I got to the museum.

Craig Harris

messages.messageBody:
Jim and all,

It is interesting to see the geographic connections, especially since the Japanese "invented" all of these techniques and motifs, right? (Reminds me of the Greeks, the Italians, etc.) See part of "Lies My Teachers Taught Me" by Bob Haynes in the most recent To-Ron for further comments along these lines.

I just saw an Indian dagger in the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco that had gold inlay on the blade done this way no doubt, actually in the kind of tendril designs we see so often on Japanese metalwork. It had a walrus ivory handle, a very attractive item. Unfortunately my notes on it's date and place are temporarily inaccessible, and my digital camera batteries died just after I got to the museum.

Craig Harris

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nunome-zogan
messages.msgSnippet: A quick check of Oppi Untracht s Jewelry Concepts and Technology yielded a few synonyms for nunome and places where it is still being practiced... Koftgari
messages.messageBody:
A quick check of Oppi Untracht's "Jewelry Concepts and Technology" yielded a few synonyms for nunome and places where it is still being practiced...

Koftgari in Trivandrum, India; Tela-kubi in Qasvin, Iran; Taraceado in Toledo, Spain.

A Google search on koftgari turned up many weapon-related links. Two on the technique are below:

http://www.ethnictourism.com/news/koft.asp
http://www.womenexcel.com/fashion/jewelmaking.htm#6

I didn't have any luck searching on the other terms.
Jim

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nunome-zogan
messages.msgSnippet: Peter, I m not aware of such a study.  It would be a great topic for an article in the Bulletin of the Metals Museum.  My impression is that nunome zogan first
messages.messageBody:
Peter,
I'm not aware of such a study. It would be a great topic for an article in the Bulletin of the Metals Museum. My impression is that nunome zogan first appears on Japanese sword fittings in the late Muromachi period. Where it originates is an even harder question, but nunome zogan is strongly associated with Ko-Shoami work and some sources place the origin of the Ko-Shoami in Kyoto.

I have seen some very sophisticated gold and silver inlay on iron from North China ca. 5th-4th C BC, and of course complex Tang metalwork, but I can't recall nunome type inlay from that time. As Rich mentioned "nunome" is seen elsewhere in the Middle East and Asia. I have seen nunome-style inlay on old European material as well. There is an "Anglo-Scandinavian" iron stirrup in the Metropolitan Museum from the 10-11th C with brass inlay that is affixed with a nunome-type technique.

I have a few pages of notes from Bob Haynes where he records various nunome cross hatching styles seen on tsuba and attempts to correlate them to their various makers.

Jim



List-eners,
Has there been a synthetic study of nunome zogan? This is the
Japanese term for the overlay techniques that places gold or silver leaf on
steel by rubbing it into/onto very fine cross hatched striations. When well
done it is very beautiful, but often it is either entirely gone or survives
only as traces. Do we know when and where it originated in Japan? And where
else is it practiced?
Peter Bleed


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.msgSnippet: ... leaf on ... When well ... survives ... And where ... Hi Pete und all, funny you are talking about this nunome zogan.......... please take a look see at

wrote:

When well

Hi Pete und all,

funny you are talking about this nunome zogan..........
please take a look see at list album ( milt's ) or
klick.........http://tinyurl.com/n77z
the two Kyo-sukashi tsuba.
One has nunome zogan applied/added on later.I deduced it's a later
application as part of the iron has been eroded resulting in lower
level ( sort of like chips ), yet there are nunome zogan intact there.

The two tsuba has identical design of Kiri mon with scroll. The
design is illustrated in Sasano's sukashi book.

milt

messages.subject: Re: Nunome-zogan
messages.msgSnippet: ... The same technique is widely used on middle eastern swords and knives. Done in both gold and silver. I have a few pieces from the middle east and India
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Peter A Bleed" <pbleed1@u...>

>And where else is it practiced?
> Peter Bleed

The same technique is widely used on middle eastern swords
and knives. Done in both gold and silver. I have a few pieces
from the middle east and India with the decor done in
nunome-zogan; generally scrolling vines and small floral
patterns.

Rich S

messages.subject: Nunome-zogan
messages.msgSnippet: List-eners, Has there been a synthetic study of nunome zogan? This is the Japanese term for the overlay techniques that places gold or silver leaf on steel by
messages.messageBody:
List-eners,
Has there been a synthetic study of nunome zogan? This is the
Japanese term for the overlay techniques that places gold or silver leaf on
steel by rubbing it into/onto very fine cross hatched striations. When well
done it is very beautiful, but often it is either entirely gone or survives
only as traces. Do we know when and where it originated in Japan? And where
else is it practiced?
Peter Bleed
